Explanation (Thanks to Paul):
“You can code and compile specifications without their bodies. Next, you can compile standalone subprograms that reference the packages. You need not fully define the package bodies until you are ready to complete the application.”

“Package public variables and cursors can persist for the life of a session. They can be shared by all subprograms that run in the environment. They let you maintain data across transactions without storing it in the database. ”

“The first time you invoke a package subprogram, Oracle Database loads the whole package into memory. Subsequent invocations of other subprograms in same the package require no disk I/O.”

questions.question_text: Which two statements are correct about PL/SQL package components? (Choose two)

choices.C: A package specification can exist without the package body.
choices.B: A package body can exist without the package specification.
choices.A: A package must have both specification and body.
choices.D: When a packaged public variable is called for the first time in a session, the entire package is loaded into memory.

discussion.content:
a) PLSQL %rowtype
b) Varray
c) Nested Table
d) Associative Array -- correct

choices.D: When you want to create a relatively small lookup table, where the collection can be constructed on memory each time a subprogram is invoked.
choices.B: When you know the number of elements in advance and the elements are usually accessed sequentially
choices.C: When you want to create a separate lookup table with multiple entries for each row of the main table, and access it through join queries
choices.A: When you want to retrieve an entire row from a table and perform calculations

questions.question_text: In which of the following scenarios would you recommend using associative arrays?

discussion.content: C is correct. Null value will always goes to 'ELSE' part. You can avoid thus by adding NVL.

comments.content: The option you are saying is C
You compare null with value.It will be ignored that's why else will be processed

discussion.content: A is correct answer, because condition v_myage <11 will be FALSE, and control will go to ELSE statement and output value.
why is not D, can you compare a null value with a data type ?

comments.content:
If condition v_myage < 11 is NOT true, (i.e. ELSE or NULL), then control will go to ELSE clause.
At this time, variable v_myage is holdng NULL value. So, above condition is NOT true, and control will move to ELSE part.

choices.B: It executes and the condition returns true.
choices.D: It fails because no value is assigned to the v_myage variable.
choices.C: It executes and control goes to the else statement.

sorry i mean,

discussion.content: AR is for relatively small lookup table

choices.A: when you want to retrieve an entire row from a table and perform calculations
choices.C: when you want to create a separate lookup table with multiple entries for each row of the main table, and access it through join queries
choices.B: when you know the number of elements in advance and the elements are usually accessed sequentially
choices.D: when you want to create a relatively small lookup table, where the collection can be constructed in memory each time a subprogram is invoked
